subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Letter connections and syllable boundaries (or, the spelling of "kangaroo")
msgSnippet: ... Alas, where syllable boundaries are to be drawn in English is a terribly vexed subject, so hard that most linguists either give up on the idea of doing so,
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:

> Connections between letters are not allowed to cross a syllable boundary.

Alas, where syllable boundaries are to be drawn in English is a terribly
vexed subject, so hard that most linguists either give up on the idea
of doing so, counting syllables rather than delimiting them, or else
simply admit that there are words where there are good reasons for saying
that one sound belongs to both syllables. Is it mon-ster, mons-ter,
or monst-er? All are defensible choices, and dictionaries just record
the more or less arbitrary rules used by printers in this matter, going
for uniformity rather than impossible correctness.

It may be that the number of ligatures is small enough that this never
matters: I haven't tried to find out. (And what about Senior QS,
where there are lots more ligatures?) But it's opening yet another
can of worms.

> Under the rules in the QM, 'kangaroo' would be spelled:
> Key,Eight,Ing,Gay,Utter,Roe,Ooze

Huh. I have At in "kangaroo".

--
"Well, I'm back." --Sam John Cowan <cowan@...>
